dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about what it was like growing up without electricity.

dialogue_content.original_text: We didn't have the convenience of lights or appliances, but it meant we spent more time together as a family.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We relied on oil lamps for light and wood stoves for heat.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like family was really central to your life back then. How did you all manage daily tasks without electricity?

dialogue_content.original_text: During the day, we'd use the sunlight for chores.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My siblings and I helped with the farm work, and in the evenings, we gathered around the table to shell peas or mend clothes by the light of the oil lamp.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard. What were some of the challenges you faced during those times?

dialogue_content.original_text: It was tough, especially during the harsh winters.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Keeping the house warm was a struggle, and we had to make sure we had enough wood stocked up.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Carrying water from the well was another big task, particularly when the ground was frozen.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like those winters were particularly challenging. How did your family prepare for them?

dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, preparing for winter was quite the task!
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We'd start by chopping and stacking firewood during the warmer months.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We also canned vegetables and preserved fruits from our garden to make sure we had plenty to eat when the snow covered the ground.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: And, of course, we made sure the animals were ready for the cold too.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So when did things change for your family on the farm?

dialogue_content.original_text: Well, it was around the time that folks started getting electricity in our area.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember the excitement when the power lines finally reached our little farm.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Suddenly, we had lights at the flick of a switch and could use appliances like a refrigerator.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We were able to use electric tools, and that reduced the manual labor a bit.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear how you adapted once electricity came to the farm.

dialogue_content.original_text: With electricity, things started to get a bit easier, but it was the year when we had to deal with a particularly bad harvest.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: The weather had been unkind to us, and we were worried about losing our crops.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My husband and I, along with our children, worked tirelessly to harvest whatever was left.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been a trying time for your family. How did you manage to get through that difficult harvest?

dialogue_content.original_text: We spent long days in the fields, and even the children helped as much as they could.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My husband had this old tractor that gave us some trouble, but with the electric tools, we managed to keep it running.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: The community was a great support too.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Neighbors would lend a hand, and we did the same for them when we could.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like that harvest was a real test for you all. What were some of the specific challenges you remember facing?

dialogue_content.original_text: That year, we had a late frost that damaged a lot of our early crops.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Then, during the summer, we faced a dry spell that left the earth parched.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We had to get creative with our irrigation, using the limited water we had as efficiently as possible.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: How did you keep the family morale up during such a tough season?

dialogue_content.original_text: We found joy in the little things, like a good meal shared together or a story told by the fire.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My husband always had a way of making us laugh, even when times were tough.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We also leaned on each other and our faith quite a bit.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: The children were so resilient, and their energy kept us going.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So, how did life on the farm continue to change after that difficult harvest?

dialogue_content.original_text: But as time went on, it became clear that the farm wasn't as sustainable as it once was for our family.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: The kids were growing up and moving to the city for jobs, and my husband and I were getting older.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Eventually, we made the difficult decision to sell the land.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been a tough decision to make. How did you feel about selling the land?

dialogue_content.original_text: The farm was such a big part of our livesâ€”it's where we raised our children and shared so many memories.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: How do you look back on your time on the farm now, after all these years?

dialogue_content.original_text: Looking back, I feel so grateful for the life we had on the farm.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: The land gave us so much, and we gave it everything we had in return.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: How do you think your experiences on the farm have shaped you as a person?

dialogue_content.original_text: Oh, the farm shaped me in so many ways.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: There were days when I thought I couldn't do any more, but I always found strength in the land and my family.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: Before we finish, Martha, what final lesson or piece of wisdom would you like to share from your experiences on the farm?

dialogue_content.original_text: Life on the farm taught me that nothing stays the same forever, and sometimes you have to adapt to keep going.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: But no matter what, the love and support of family and community can get you through even the toughest times.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
